facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 250 of 1961 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 250 of 1961. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated June 16, 1958,

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated June 16, 1958, of Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original Decree No. 144 of 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated June 16, 1958, of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original Decree No. 144 of 1948. Sen, S. N. M

facts.text: Suit instituted on December 6, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: The suit out of which this appeal arises was instituted as long ago as December 6, 1945, and has had rather a long and chequered career. The plaintiff,

facts.text: Plaintiff auction purchased entire revenue paying estate, Touzi No. 6 of the 24 Parganas, on January 6, 1936.

anchor.surface_text: instituted the suit for ejectment of the defendants from the disputed property on the ground that he had annulled the defendants interests, whatever they were, under s. 37 of the Bengal Land Revenue Sales Act  Central Act XI of 1859 , by virtue of his auction purchase, on January 6, 1936,

facts.text: Plaintiff obtained possession from the Collector in May-June, 1936.

anchor.surface_text: of the entire revenue paying estate, Touzi No. 6 of the 24 Parganas companylectorate. After the auction purchase aforesaid, he obtained possession from the Collector in May-June, 1936,

facts.text: Plaintiff annulled all intermediary interests except those protected under s. 37 of Act XI of 1859, in June 1936.

anchor.surface_text: and there after annulled and avoided all intermediary interests except those protected under s. 37 of Act XI of 1859, by appropriate numberices, in or about June, 1936 The land in dispute was described in the plaint as Mal land of the said Touzi

facts.text: Land in dispute described as Mal land of Touzi No. 6 and other Touzies; plaintiff seeks khas possession to 1/6th share jointly with defendants.

anchor.surface_text: The land in dispute was described in the plaint as Mal land of the said Touzi and other Touzies and the plaintiff asked for Khas possession to the extent of his 1/6th share, jointly with the defendants.

facts.text: First defendant contested that suit lands were not Mal lands, never assessed to revenue, not included in Mal assets of Touzi No. 6; claimed Brabmottar Lakheraj lands never in regularly assessed estate Touzi No. 6.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was companytested by the first defendant-respondent on a number of grounds, of which it is necessary to mention only the companytention of fact, that the suit lands were number Mal lands, as alleged by the plaintiff, and had never been assessed to revenue, number were they included in the Mal assets of Touzi No. 6. It was also claimed by the defendants that the lands in dispute were Brabmottar Lakheraj lands which were never within the regularly assessed estate, Touzi No. 6.

facts.text: Main issue: Is the land in dispute Mal land of Touzi No. 6 or Lakheraj?

anchor.surface_text: Hence, the main issue, on question of fact, between the parties was Is the land in dispute Mal land of Touzi No. 6 or is it Lakheraj?

facts.text: Subordinate Judge held in favour of plaintiff by judgment dated April 20, 1948, decreed suit for possession with mesne profits.

anchor.surface_text: On this question, the learned Subordinate judge, by his judgment and decree dated April 20, 1948, held in favour of the plaintiff and decreed the suit for possession, with mesne profits, to be ascertained later.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge held land was Mal land of Touzi No. 6 and other Touzies; defendants' interest not protected under s.37 Act 1859.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Subordinate judge held that the land in suit was Mal land of the Touzi No. 6 and other Touzies, and that the defendants interest was number protected from annulment under s. 37 of the Act of 1859.

facts.text: First defendant appealed to High Court in July 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The first defendant appealed to the High Court in July, 1948 and the appeal was pending when the Amending Act was enacted.

facts.text: Bengal Land Revenue Sales West Bengal Amendment Act VII of 1950 came into force on March 15, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: the scope and effect of ss. 4 7 of the Bengal Land Revenue Sales  West Bengal Amendment  Act  West Bengal Act VII of 1950 -which hereinafter will be referred to as the Amending Act-which came into force on March 15, 1950.

facts.text: Appeal hearing before Division Bench on March 8, 1954; judges called for finding on whether possession delivered before Amending Act.

anchor.surface_text: When the appeal was put up for hearing before a Division Bench on March 8, 1954, the learned judges thought it necessary to call for a finding on the question whether ,possession had already been delivered to the successful plaintiff in execution of the decree of the Trial Court, before the Amending Act came into force.

facts.text: Plaintiff filed sworn petition claiming possession obtained on March 29, 1949 in execution.

anchor.surface_text: This enquiry was instituted in view of the sworn petition filed on behalf of the plaintiff at the hearing in the High Court that he had already obtained possession in execution of the decree on March 29, 1949,

facts.text: Defendant contested plaintiff's statement on possession.

anchor.surface_text: and that, therefore, s. 7 of the Amending Act did number render the appeal void. The defendant- appellant in the High Court companytested this statement fact.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge found possession delivered to decree holder on March 29, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Subordinate judge submitted a finding to the High Court to the effect that possession of the disputed property had been delivered to the decree holder, as alleged by him, on March 29, 1949.

facts.text: High Court accepted finding that possession delivered to decree-holder on March 29, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court accepted the finding of the Trial Court that possession had been delivered to the decree-holder in pursuance of the Trial Courts decree.

facts.text: Plaintiff made application for delivery of possession on March 28, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the plaintiff had made an application for delivery of possession on March 28, 1949, and the following day, on March 29, 1949,

facts.text: Judgment debtor filed petition on March 29, 1949 for one month's time to bring stay order from High Court and stay of process.

anchor.surface_text: the judgment debtor, who had already preferred his appeal to the High Court, fiied a petition to the Court praying for one months time to bring a stay order from the High Court and for stay of process meanwhile.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge disposed of petition ordering recall and put up in presence of both parties, inform Nazir.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Subordinate judge dispo- sed of the petition, in the following terms Judgment-debtor files a petition praying for one months time to bring a stay order and for stay of process in the meantime. Heard learned lawyer. Re-call and put up in the presence of both parties Inform Nazir.

facts.text: High Court held delivery of possession without authority and a nullity.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court very elaborately companysidered the effect of this order with reference to decided cases of different High Courts, and came to the companyclusion that the delivery of possession which had been given to the decree-holder was without authority and hence a nullity.

facts.text: High Court held land in dispute part of permanent tenure held rent-free (Niskar), protected under ss.4 & 7 Amending Act.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court then companysidered the effect of ss. 4 7 of the Amending Act and came to the companyclusion that the land in dispute being part of a permanent tenure, held rent-free  Niskar , was pro- tected under the provisions of the sections aforesaid.

facts.text: High Court held decree passed by Trial Court void under s.7(2) Amending Act.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court took the view that the decree passed by the Trial Court had become void under s. 7  2  of the Amending Act,

facts.text: High Court allowed appeal, set aside trial court judgment and decree, directed order of abatement and refund of court fees.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the High Court allowed the appeal, set aside the judgment and decree of the Trial Court and directed that Court to record an order of abatement of the suit and to pass an order for refund of companyrt fees in favour of the plaintiff.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds suit abated under s.7(1)(a) on March 15, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Hence, in partial disagreement with the High Court, we hold that the suit pending in the High Court on appeal had abated on March 15, 1950, under s.7 1  a  as soon as the Amending Act came into force.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal fails and is dismissed, though number for the same reasons as prevailed in the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: For section 37 of the said Act, the following section shall be substituted, namely 37.  1  The purchaser of an entire estate in the permanently settled districts of West Bengal sold under this Act for the recovery of arrears due on account of the same, shall acquire the estate free from all encumbrances which may have been imposed after the time of settlement and shall be entitled to avoid and annul all tenures, holdings and leases with the following exceptions -  a  tenures and holdings which have been held from the time of the permanent settlement either free of rent or at a fixed rent or fixed rate of rent, and  b   i  tenures and holdings number included in exception  a  above made, and other leases of land whether or number. for purposes . companynected with agriculture or horticulture, existing at the date of issue of the numberification sale of the estate under this Act x x x x

holdings.text: The suit pending in the High Court on appeal had abated on March 15, 1950, under s.7(1)(a) as soon as the Amending Act came into force.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Suit pending on appeal at commencement (continuation of original suit); could not be validly instituted under new s.37 as tenure protected by cl.(b)(i); s.7(1)(a) causes abatement of such pending suits.

holdings.text: An appeal is a continuation of the original suit; the suit was pending in the High Court on appeal at the commencement of the Amending Act.

anchor.surface_text: There cannot be the least doubt that the suit was pending in the High Court, on appeal, at the commencement of the Amending Act, it being well-settled that an appeal is a continuation of the original suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well-settled principle applied to facts; appeal filed July 1948, pending March 15, 1950.

holdings.text: The suit could not have been validly instituted had the Amending Act been in operation, as the defendants' tenure was protected under cl.(b)(i) of the substituted s.37.

anchor.surface_text: Section 37  1   a  would not come into operation in this case because the finding is that the defendants had failed to prove the existence of tenure since the time of the Permanent Settlement.

holdings.reasoning_summary: New s.37 cl.(a) inapplicable (no proof from Permanent Settlement); cl.(b)(i) applies as tenure existed before 1910 (pre-sale notification), per High Court finding.

holdings.text: Section 4 of the Amending Act is prima facie prospective, but s.7 is retrospective insofar as applicable to pending litigations.

anchor.surface_text: But when we look to the provisions of s. 7, it becomes abundantly clear, as rightly pointed out by the High Court, that the section was retrospective in so far as it was made applicable to pending litigations.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of s.4 substitution; s.7 explicitly applies to pending suits/appeals/proceedings/decrees.

holdings.text: Section 7(1)(b) does not apply to the appeal pending in the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: As will presently appear, s. 7  1   b  would not apply to the appeal pending in the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.7(1)(b) for appeals by unsuccessful plaintiffs against final decrees; here appeal by defendant against trial decree.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary as suit already abated under s.7(1)(a) on commencement date, prior to delivery consideration.

holdings.text: The present suit is one for ejectment in pursuance of s.37 of Act XI of 1859, hence s.7(1)(a) comes into operation.

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that the present suit is one for ejectment in pursuance of s. 37 of Act XI of 1859. Hence, s. 7  1   a  comes into operation.
